Fields.DialogueText: Hey, Captain! You busy?
Not at all. What can I...
Great! Hold this.
Wait, what... oof!
Whoa, be careful with that! I was up all night tinkering with the piston valve!
Lexington, what am I holding?
Prototype spud cannon, Captain!
You're making a potato gun?
I made a potato gun! I just need you to test it.

Fields.MenuText: Lexington, are you sure this is safe?
All right, I'm in. Where do you want me?
Can't you do this on your own time?

Fields.DialogueText: 'Course I am!
Right here is good! That's what I like about the sea... you can aim anywhere!
Nope! I did the math, and I'm just a hair too light to shoot it and stay standing!
Okay... how do I do this?
Just hold it like... yeah, there you go. Taking the wind into account... turn about 30... no, 33 degrees that way.
Now I pull the trigger?
Yep!
FWUNT
Aaah!
Wow, look at it fly!... Oh! Captain, are you all right?
Pending some ice...
Eh, you can walk it off. Sure gave that Morgana over there something to think about, though!
I suppose we did. Please help me up so I can walk it off.
Aye-aye!
@BATTLE
Do the Powers That Be know about your clandestine munitions program?
I wouldn't call it that, Captain - but it sounds keen when you put it that way!
What do you even need with a potato gun?
It sure drilled the Morgana, didn't it?
It'll take more than a potato to slow them down.
That's why it's a prototype! You don't break the sound barrier without flirting with it a little.
You can fire a potato at supersonic speed?
Don't just think potatoes, Captain, you're making me hungry! If I can build a supersonic pneumatic weapon out of junk, imagine what we could outfit the crew with...

Fields.MenuText: I'm pretty sure we have pistols for that already.
I don't think it would be practical for a sailor to carry around something that big.
Tomato guns?

Fields.DialogueText: ... Well, yeah, I guess... My idea's more fun, though.
Prototype, remember? It's going to be handheld in a year!
Of course not! The ammunition would be way too soft.
It's great that you want to help out, but there are regulations about what we can carry. Blame governments and contractors.
What they don't know won't hurt them, right?
It's not them I'm worried about. We don't need any of you mothballed while there are Morganas to worry about.
If you say so, Captain. Hey, speaking of Morganas...
You know, you're not under those weapon regulations. Another opening shot wouldn't hurt.
Now you're speaking my language!
@BATTLE
... Almost there... just have to...
Lexington, did you hear the alarm?
AAAH! Shoot, shoot, and double shoot!
Did I interrupt anything?
Captain... well, no, never mind. Looks all right to me!
Do I want to know?
'Course you do! Let's take care of the Morgana first, though, she's supposed to be a nasty one!
@BATTLE
So what was it that you were so panicked about?
Turned out to be nothing, Captain! I just looked away from a propane tank for a second. Thought I'd left the valve open!

Fields.MenuText: Well, thank goodness you didn't.
What do you need with a propane tank?
You need to be more careful. What if there had been a gas leak?

Fields.DialogueText: I would have been fine, Captain, but one spark and all my notes would be up in smoke!
Combustion-based spud gun! There's only so much that pneumatics have to offer.
Don't worry about it, Captain! Nothing I can't clean up with an extinguisher grenade and a mop.
If the Morganas don't blow us all up, you just might.
No chance! I always have a backup plan.
If it involves putting out fires, you might want to revise your initial plan.
But those are the best kind...
Captain, you hear that?
What? What's going on?
Give it a second. Belles have more sensitive hearing...
What are we listening for?
... Captain! Shut down the radios, right now!
I'll put an order through to... what the hell?
Hear that? That's why. We've got Morganas!
@BATTLE
That was rough. What was all that interference before the fight?
Morgana chatter. They like to try it every once in a while to get the crew down.
All I heard was static.
Weird. I guess they weren't talking to you.

Fields.MenuText: Why wouldn't I have heard it?
What were they saying?
They have radio too?

Fields.DialogueText: No idea, but I guarantee you wouldn't have wanted to.
All kinds of nasty stuff. It's kind of like human propaganda.
Not exactly, but they can talk on your frequencies. Crazy talk, mostly.
Belles can hear it, but we don't really pay attention. It's like having an annoying cousin that keeps writing to you.
This isn't good. It's bad enough fighting monster ships. We don't need them messing with our radios - to say nothing of trying to undermine morale.
Hmm... you leave that to me, Captain!
Leave what to you?
I'll tell you when the Morganas call again!
Lexington, are you in here?
Hey, Captain! Check this out, this is amazing!
Does this have anything to do with why the radio crew is missing?
I told 'em to take a break. Don't worry, I got the signalmen on flags!
I just want to know why you've taken over the radio room.
Remember when we were talking about the Morgana broadcasts?

Fields.MenuText: I remember. Have you found a way to counter them?
I talked to the crew about them. Not everyone's heard them, but there are a few stories that are... disturbing.
Remind me?

Fields.DialogueText: Sort of. I've been working all day on some way to retaliate.
Well, it's just words, Captain. Don't let it get you down.
Keep up, Captain! You never know what you might need to do to stay on top.
I thought the radiomen deserved time off, but I've been playing with frequencies and I think I've finally found... yes! There she is!
... the sea is your tomb. We, your gravekeepers. Your race, a legion of corpses...
That voice... is that a Morgana?
Weird, aren't they? But I figure if they can talk to us, why not talk back?
Wait, Lexington, I don't...
Hey! Is this Malice? Nice hull! You scavenge it from a Hooverville?
Lexington, what are you doing? You're just going to make her angry!
I hope so! You can't shoot straight if you're seeing red!
@BATTLE
Package for you, Lexington.
Thanks, Captain! I didn't know you were pulling mail shifts.
I'm not. Nobody seems to want to touch your mail these days.
You know, you get one box that happens to be ticking...
What was that one, anyway?
Cuckoo clock!
You take it apart to see what made it tick?
No, I actually just wanted to spruce up my quarters a little. But that's a great idea!
So what's in this box?
I'll tell you after this Morgana goes away.
You mean after we drive it off.
Oh, that's the easy part. Barely worth mentioning, am I right?
@BATTLE
Morning, Captain! Can you hold this in place for me?
Sure thing. Science project?
Something like that. There's been kind of a craze for new sea-going technologies since the Morganas showed up, and some of it is really keen - like this idea to get boats floating on beds of air.
Small boats, I take it. You're not planning to fit yourself with ten thousand electric fans, all pointed down.
Not just yet. I'm starting from scratch with a vacuum and some plywood. Tsiolkovsky had some neat ideas for sustaining the lift...
So I hold it like this?
Just until I've got the screw in place... there! All done.

Fields.MenuText: Is all this really necessary? What could an aircraft carrier want with a levitating raft?
Looks like something out of those magazines. Think it'll work?
Neat. Planning on making the crew some?

Fields.DialogueText: You don't spend your time with pilots without wanting to do some flying!
Maybe. Whether it does or not, I'm taking notes!
If I don't get bored. But I rarely get bored!
I hope you're not planning on using the crew for your testing. I've heard some... interesting stories about the other Belles' methods.
Don't you worry, Captain. I always give the crew a choice. They can either volunteer...
Wait, when you said "all done..."
Or stay out of the way.
Lexington, I... Stop!
Whoa!
*SPLASH*
Well, it definitely floated on a bed of air for a second or two there.
That it did. I'll have to tone down the thrust on the next one... But wasn't that amazing!?
The Morgana certainly noticed. Scramble the pilots so there can be a next one.
@BATTLE
I think I've solved the morale issue, Captain!
About the Morgana broadcasts, you mean?
It's like I said, Captain... there's no reason we can't just talk back. I taught the radiomen some choice Belle insults.
I wasn't aware Belles had specific insults for each other.
Oh, definitely! And they work even better on the Morganas. Some of 'em really don't like being told they're not aerodynamic...

Fields.MenuText: Some things you have to be a ship to understand.
Or that their parents were fishing vessels?
You're not worried about making them mad?

Fields.DialogueText: Think about it, Captain. It'll come to you!
Eh... keep working on your material.
Of course not! The best way to get over your fear of something is to laugh at it.
So your solution to raise crew morale is to broadcast insults before battle.
I'd say it's working so far! The radio room's never been happier! Some of them are even requesting longer shifts just to come up with more jokes. Actually, that gives me an idea...
Most things do. That's good, though. Creativity is important.
Isn't it? If there's one thing war's good for, it's innovation!
Let's innovate after this Morgana is gone.
Roger! Hey, Murder, you fire like water!
@BATTLE
Read it and weep, Captain!
I think I'll ask some questions instead.
I know what you're thinking. How'd I come up with such a great poster?
It just seems a little excessive for a short story contest.
Go big or go home, I say!

Fields.MenuText: Where did you find the time to make this?
Is that supposed to be me?
It's certainly... exciting?

Fields.DialogueText: It's amazing what you can do with some canvas and paint. And it sure beats sleeping!
I thought you'd look more heroic with some epaulettes... and a proton cannon!
If this is exciting, just think of the submissions!
Do we even have any writers on the ship?
We'll find out, won't we? Whoever they are, they oughta keep us entertained between skirmishes.
All right, I'll bite. Are you entering?
Who, me? I'm the one who suggested it! It wouldn't be fair if I put my name in. Unless... Captain, that's a great idea!
What's a great idea?
If you judge it, there's no problem with me entering! You're the best, you know that?
I didn't agree to anything!
Neither did Superman, and look where he ended up!
Saving the world isn't at all like judging a contest.
It's a start. You never know who the next Jules Verne might be!
Hmm?
Read a book, Captain. And get to the bridge, there's Morganas on the loose!
@BATTLE
How are the stories coming, Captain?
They... vary.
I thought they might. What are you reading right now?

Fields.MenuText: The stirring adventure of a man and his destroyer.
It's about a girl who delivers newspapers, and... that's it, really.
A spy story set at the United States Naval Academy. It's pretty predictable.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that certainly doesn't sound bad! Although it'd be better with an aircraft carrier, in my humble opinion...
That can be... interesting? I think?
Weird. I swear I've read that one before...
I'm surprised how many of these short stories feature Belles, actually.
Ooh, let me see one!
Your funeral.
"Nagato's raven-black tresses framed a fierce cinnabar blush, making her look like an amorous checkerboard, and with a tug of the laces on... " Captain! This is lewd!
You're the one who decided the submissions should be anonymous.
Hmph. Romance is boring, anyway. What's wrong with good old science fiction?
To each their own.
No, seriously! I'll lend you some H.G. Wells sometime, he's one of the best.
The Time Machine, War of the Worlds... he's just put out a new one, I think. The Holy Terror or something.
"Ghost ships? More like toast ships!"
We're coming up on some Morganas, Captain. I really oughta teach the crew better insults.
Truth is stranger than fiction...
@BATTLE
You finish War of the Worlds, Captain?
Just the other day. It... really hits close to home.
I bet it does. Not all the Belles are big readers, but all the ones I talked to loved War of the Worlds. Especially the part with that one ironclad...
HMS Thunder Child!
Yeah, her! She took out three Martians on her own! Isn't that the coolest thing you've ever read?

Fields.MenuText: It's all right, I guess.
You sure it was three? We never really find out about the third one...
Not as cool as being able to talk to the ships.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... I guess Wells isn't for everyone. Lovecraft might be more your style.
Yeah, but that's the fun of it... it's up to the reader's imagination!
Well, obviously...  but it's fun to see a little of yourself in the things you read.
Oh, yeah, and I heard the Campbell Playhouse wants to do a radio drama about the Morganas! With Orson Welles and everything!
You don't think that would be in poor taste?
It's about more than that, Captain. You saw how much fun the radio crew were having sassing the Morganas.
If you can't tell stories about your enemy, you're going to keep being afraid.
Even scary stories?
Well, they don't all have to have happy endings. But ours will!
Not if this Morgana has anything to say about it.
Then let's speak louder!
@BATTLE
You read the paper this morning?
The paper? Oh, um... no, Captain, I don't... read. I don't read.
All right, I know that's not true. What's on your mind?
What are you talking about? Nothing's wrong! I'm completely fine.
... Okay, then. Anyway, there was this interview with your sister Saratoga and her Captain Gault, and I thought...
Grrr! One of these days I'm going to sink her myself!
What's wrong? It's not every day you see family in the news.
Page four, Captain. Third paragraph.
Let's see..."Fleet Problem IX taught us both a lot about ourselves. I love my sister Lexington very much, and I know that she's a fast learner. One day she'll return the favor."
She knows I hate it when she brings up IX! And here she is, blabbing about it to whoever will listen!
That's the one where you were defending the Panama Canal and Saratoga got one past you?
Stupid, lying Saratoga, thinking she can make me look bad... I got her back in X, but does she ever mention that? If I were a battlecruiser like I was supposed to be, I'd show her!

Fields.MenuText: If you were a battlecruiser, you wouldn't have your team of ace pilots.
Fleet Problem IX taught the Navy a lot about carriers. You played an important part.
Calm down. She's your only sister.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but... ugh! She's so annoying! And she sounds so nice about it, which makes it even more annoying!
That's exactly the way she'd put it! She wouldn't be so smug if I had been there!
That's what ticks me off! What does she have that I don't?
You'll get your interview one of these days. You can gloat all you want about Fleet Problem X then.
Hmph. If they hadn't canceled XXI, we'd settle the score once and for all.
Consider these Morganas a tiebreaker?
Oh, I'll break more than just the tie...
@BATTLE
Okay, Lexington, I think we have a winner!
Swell! I can't wait to read it!
You won't need to. The winner will read their story out loud over dinner the night it's announced.
... Is... is that so?
What's wrong? You look worried.
What, me worry? No, everything's fine! I didn't even enter!
You what? I thought you were all excited about entering the contest.
Yeah, but I... changed my mind. A while ago, actually. Oh, well.

Fields.MenuText: You're not afraid of reading before an audience, are you?
Okay, if you're sure. I would have liked to read something of yours, though.
That's all right. There's always next time.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not! I'm not afraid of anything! Morganas don't scare me, so why should this?
You see, the thing is I read a lot... but I'm not much of a writer.
N-next time? Oh, well... I'll probably pass on that one as well.
Best to leave the writing to the masters anyway.
Every great writer had to start somewhere.
Yep, no doubt. Oh, hey, there's a Morgana nearby! Good old Belle senses, right?
@BATTLE
That was such a good story! I've still got goosebumps.
I'm not really one for science fiction, but Signalman Ulyanov has quite the reading voice. The title could use some work, though.
"The Day Venus Turned Purple?" Yeah, maybe, but at least it gets you curious.
Curious about what Ulyanov was thinking when he came up with it.
Oh, lighten up! A good story hooks you with the title alone. Here, check this out!
What's this?
September issue of Amazing Stories. Just give the table of contents a look.
"Face in the Sky", "Beast of the Island..."
Don't forget "Rocket Race to Luna!" That one's my favorite.

Fields.MenuText: The title definitely makes me want to read it.
Why is that?
I guess so. It doesn't seem plausible, though.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, right? There's so many questions in it!
Because it gets you thinking!
That's the whole point of science fiction! It's all about speculation.
Like, how easy is space travel that you can race to the moon? How do the racers all do it? And what do you win in the future? It's so fun to think about!
Do you think we'll go to the moon someday?
I think everything in science fiction will come true one way or another. Maybe not today, but people come up with new things every day! It's all about solving problems, in the end.
Life finds a way.
Oh, I like that! Mind if I keep it?
Sure. You can use it in one of your stories.
But I... that is... Morgana incoming!
@BATTLE
Captain, I've been thinking...
Uh-oh.
Hear me out. Remember the potato gun I was building?
It almost blew me overboard. How could I forget?
I might have finally figured out how to get a leg up on Saratoga.

Fields.MenuText: We're supposed to be fighting the Morganas. I don't think we have time to be pranking the other Belles.
And how might that be?
Potato bombardment?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, there's all kinds of time! You've just got to look for it.
The Navy's going to want to put us together eventually, right? We worked pretty well on Fleet Problem XIX, after all.
You read my mind!
There'll come a time when Saratoga and I team up again, and only one of us will have potato guns on our side.
We'll finish off a Morgana... and then she gets a spud in the back! Imagine her face when...
Let me stop you right there. Isn't it more important for us to do our job?
But we're so good at it! We can spare some time to mess with my sister.
That's exactly my point. How do you think she'll spin it in the next interview? "My sister Lexington is a good soldier, but she can be so childish..."
Grr... that's exactly the tone of voice she uses, too. I guess you're right. I'll just have to fight better than she does.
Shouldn't be hard. Here's a Morgana now to prove it.
I knew I picked the right captain!
@BATTLE
Lexington, I've just had the strangest letter from Washington...
Ooh! I bet I know what it's about! Is it the movie thing?
How did you know?
I've been hearing rumors for a while. Supposedly a bunch of studios are interested in making movies about us!
The Belles, you mean?
Isn't it keen? Hollywood wants to talk to us! To me!

Fields.MenuText: I think it's a little early to be thinking about stardom.
Hollywood's a big place. Are we talking about anyone with actual influence? Do we know?
What do the other Belles think?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't tell me you've never thought about being in pictures, Captain!
Fritz Lang, James Whale... imagine working for Mr. Bride of Frankenstein himself!
Some of them aren't interested, but that's mostly the boring ones.
Anyway, it's been a while since a really good sci-fi picture has come out. It's all horror and serials these days. Nothing wrong with that, of course.
Yeah, if you were going to put down Buck Rogers, I would've had to step in.
Wouldn't dream of it.
How do you know about movies, anyway? We get a few, but you can't go on land for the full experience.
Oh, all the American Belles know King Kong and stuff. Just part of our heritage!
Well, we'll discuss this as it develops. Looks like the Morganas are knocking again.
Better put on a good show, then!
@BATTLE
You too, Ibarazaki! Stay out of trouble, okay?
Was that one of the pilots?
You don't know all of the crew, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: You know what the turnover was like over the last month. Introductions have been... hurried.
You do?
Not all, but I'm working on it.

Fields.DialogueText: But that's part of being the captain! If you were an aircraft carrier, wouldn't you want to know everyone on board?
Of course! A good carrier knows the name and hometown of everyone who serves on her. Besides, humans are fun!
Well, we'll have to work faster! You never know who you might need in a pinch.
I thought it was an instinct thing for Belles.
That's not exactly how we work. We know where everyone is on board, but not always who. Can you name every bone in your body, Captain?
No, but what does that...
See? You need them and they're inside you, but you wouldn't know what they were unless you opened yourself up to look.
Thank you for that thought.
Any time!
I didn't mean...
Now let's open up that Morgana!
@BATTLE
Soooo... when's the next one?
The next what?
You know what I'm talking about! We need to have another contest!
Are you going to participate in this one?
... Maybe not. Why?
You like reading a lot, and I know you wanted to be in the first contest.
But that doesn't mean I want to do this one!
Why not? You know what makes a good story. Why not write one?
Because... because it's weird!
It's science fiction.
No, it's... look, think of it this way. Don't you wonder what the author is thinking when you read a story?

Fields.MenuText: Wouldn't that be evident from the text?
But it's not the author you're reading. It's his story.
I'm not sure I know what you're getting at.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, not necessarily. That's the fun part, though!
It's a part of the author. That's what a story is!
How should I explain it? Um...
Think of a story like a page in a diary. You're reading what someone's thinking and feeling, but they just express it in a different way.
And you're worried people will know what you're thinking?
Well, not really, but... I mean... I don't know! It's just so... personal!
Everyone gets stage fright, Lexington.
... Not during battle! Morganas ahoy!
I swear you only talk about these things right before a battle.
I don't plan it like that, Captain, honest! ... But it does come in handy.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
In the mood for a little action, Captain?
I have misgivings. I had only three pages left to go in the chapter, Lexington. Three!
War is hell, Captain.
@BATTLE
What a workout! All right, pilots, hit the mess if you're all right or the infirmary if you aren't. You earned it!
You've got a great rapport going with the crew. How do you do it?
Belles are just naturally intriguing! Can't you tell?

Fields.MenuText: I imagine the crew would get used to a talking ship eventually.
And naturally full of themselves, it seems.
I never can tell what you'll get up to, I have to admit.

Fields.DialogueText: True, but there's more to us than just the way we're built!
Hey! You try blowing holes in a Morgana and see if you don't get a little cocky!
Good! You've always got to try new things.
It's a good thing. Some of the Belles are a little more distant than the others.
Takes all kinds, doesn't it?
A handful have been through full crews already. And not just because of Morgana attacks, I hear.
I tell you what... I don't envy the crew on those Nazi Belles. Those girls rub me the wrong way. There's just something wrong about "one people, one nation, one leader..."
I'm sure every nation in this war has its issues.
I suppose so. That'd be a great story, wouldn't it?
What would?
The Belles! Who we are, where we're from, how we're affected by our nations' issues, what makes us tick... are we our own people, or just reflections of where we're from?
I think humans have been asking that same question for longer than you've been around.
That's why you write, isn't it? To find the answer.
There might not even be an answer.
Or a gazillion answers! That's the best part.
Come on, you're the one who suggested the whole contest in the first place.
Captain, I just think there are a hundred people on board who write better than me.
Only one way to find out.
What will I even write about?
That's for you to decide.
Look, I just got the new Amazing Stories in this morning. Go away.
If you say so.
Thank you.
Saratoga should find it funny, at least.
That's funny, I thought you said Saratoga.
When was the last time you talked to your sister? I'm sure she'd love to hear about how you backed down from a challenge.
... Fine. I'll enter. But on two conditions.
Name them.
First, pseudonyms only.
Done.
Second... I'll have my revenge, and it will be swift and brutal.
Take it.
You could protest a little.
I'll leave that to the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Can I have your opinion on something?
Shoot.
Can sunsets ooze?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not helping you with your story. It would be a conflict of interest.
You're the writer. You figure it out.
Have you ever seen one ooze?

Fields.DialogueText: You're the one who bullied me into it! You owe me.
What do you think I've been trying to do for an hour?
I just asked you... You know what? I think I see your point.
The deadline's right around the corner. You'd better hurry.
I know, I know! This sort of thing doesn't write itself.
I thought you writer types could find inspiration anywhere.
That's our blessing. That's our curse. When you see interesting things everywhere, it's impossible to choose between them!
We live in a world where warships come to life and fight ghost ships. You'll think of something.
Hmph. Maybe I'll ask this Morgana what she thinks.
@BATTLE
You have a minute, Captain?
Of course. I was just about to congratulate you on the last battle. I've been finalizing my reports, and...
Yep. Oh, speaking of a job well done... here.
You finally finished the story?
Took me the whole night, but sleep is overrated anyway.
Congratulations! I can't wait to read it. What's it about?
If I told you that, you'd know which one was mine!
I figured you wouldn't fall for that. Just put it on the stack there with the rest.
... Hmm... Captain, these are all under pseudonyms, right?
That's right.
Nobody's used their real name.
Not a one.
Perfect.
Hey, careful with that!
No worries, Captain! My story's right there... in the middle of the pile... somewhere. You're welcome to guess which one!
I think I'll pass.
@BATTLE
Honestly, I can't believe that Morgana was still capable of moving once the pilots were done with her.
Captain! You're looking pleased - what's up?
I posted the winner in the mess hall.
I saw! What was the title again? I was in a rush earlier and didn't see it.

Fields.MenuText: Some Western thriller. "Rodeo in the Rockies," I think it was called.
"And the Stars Wept." Sounded like a space story.
A horror story, actually. "As It Drew Nearer."

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I love Westerns! I've never been in that part of the country, but somehow they remind me of home.
Now that's how you do a title!
I hope whoever wrote that one has a good speaking voice! The delivery can really make or break a good scary story.
I'll be looking forward to the reading. It should be a good opportunity to meet another crew member.
You don't know them?
Pseudonyms, remember? All I know is that the winning story was written by an Isaac Davis.
Well, that doesn't tell us anything. We'll have to wait until the reading, won't we?
Assuming these Morganas let us get to it.
Of course they will! I like to think we've come to an understanding.
Is that so?
Yep! I understand how to blow them up and they understand that it hurts.
@BATTLE
Okay, ladies and gentlemen, please join me in giving a warm round of applause to our winning writer, Isaac Davis.
Mr. Davis, please do us the honor of reading your piece!
... Is Mr. Davis here tonight? Going once... going twice...
No time for that, Captain! I'm sensing a Morgana presence, a big one!
Looks like we're going to have to postpone our entertainment. Action stations, everyone, you know what to do!
@BATTLE
I'm glad that's over. You'd think the Morganas wanted front-row seats.
Piece of cake! Too bad we didn't get to hear the reading, though.
Another day. You know, I've been doing some reading of my own.
Oh? What about?
A little history, as it happens. You know all about the Battles of Lexington and Concord?
Of course! It's my namesake, after all! The first battles of the Revolution, the shot heard 'round the world... it's one of the best stories I know!
That it is. And how do Belle memories work, exactly? Can you name the soldiers who fought in the battles?
Like I fought alongside them! There was brigadier general William Heath... Joseph Warren, who sent Paul Revere out to warn everyone...
And a Minuteman captain... what was his name? Isaac Davis?
... Yeah. Him too.

Fields.MenuText: Why him, if I may ask?
Come on, you've had your fun. Admit that you wrote it.
Don't look so embarrassed. It was a really good story.

Fields.DialogueText: He was a good soldier. His men were well equipped and well trained. He's kind of an inspiration.
Okay, fine! He was the first American officer killed in battle. You're nosy enough to know that already!
I just picked the name because I admire him. I'm not trying to compare us, I just... wait, you really think so?
I talked to some of the crew about it over dinner. They really want to know who Isaac Davis is. Ours, not the Revolution's.
Hate to disappoint, Captain...
I understand. But will Captain Davis be writing any more stories?
Well, he's a little shy. His captain had better read them.
That can be arranged.
Then he'd love to.
I've hardly seen you this past week. Keeping busy?
I blame you, Captain! Between the book and the fan letters, I've been writing just about nonstop.
Word's getting out about our battles, Captain! There's rumors that Warner Brothers wants to make a movie about them.

Fields.MenuText: I have difficulty imagining any actress measuring up to you, Lexington.
Don't let the fame go to your head, now.

Fields.DialogueText: Whoever she is, she'd better know how to fire this rifle!
I won't if you don't!
Okay, there's more than I expected to unpack there.
First things first - you're writing a book?
It's not going to be long, but it's a start.
What's it about?
It's about a captain who asked too many questions and got a potato to the face. Don't rush me!
Okay, okay. I can be patient! What about the fan letters, though?
